componenttext: Welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Analyst Call. My Name is Ellen, and I will be operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to Brad Alexander. Mr. Alexander, you may begin.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to FMC Technologies' Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. Our news release and financial statements issued yesterday can be found on our website. I would like to caution you with respect to any forward-looking statements
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to FMC Technologies' Fourth Quarter 2014 Earnings Conference Call. Our news release and financial statements issued yesterday can be found on our website. I would like to caution you with respect to any forward-looking statements made during this call. Although these forward-looking statements are based on our current expectations, beliefs and assumptions regarding future developments and business conditions, they are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in or implied by these statements. 
Known material factors that could cause our actual results to differ from our projected results are described in our 10-K, 10-Q and other filings with the SEC. We wish to caution you not to place undue reliance on any forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date hereof. We undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any of our forward-looking statements after the date they are made, whether as a result of information, future events or otherwise.
I will now turn the call over to John Gremp, FMC Technologies' Chairman, President and CEO.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to our Fourth Quarter 2014 Conference Call. With me today is Maryann Seaman, our CFO. I'll begin my comments today focusing on our performance both on the fourth quarter and for the full Year. I'll then discuss our current 2015 marke
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to our Fourth Quarter 2014 Conference Call. With me today is Maryann Seaman, our CFO. I'll begin my comments today focusing on our performance both on the fourth quarter and for the full Year. I'll then discuss our current 2015 market outlook, Maryann will provide specifics on our quarterly and full year financial performance and our financial outlook for 2015. And then we'll open up the call for your questions.
2014 was a very successful year for FMC Technologies. We achieved record revenue and operating income in both our Subsea Technologies and our Surface Technologies segments. Company earnings were $0.72 per diluted share in the quarter and a record $2.72 for the year. This excludes the gain related to the sale of our Material Handling business and represents a 30% decrease over our prior year performance.
Maryann will provide further detail on 2 items that impacted our earnings. Company revenue for the quarter was $2.2 billion taking our full year total to $7.9 million, an 11% increase from 2013. In Subsea, we successfully executed a significant backlog, our focus on execution that began 4 years ago has greatly improve our ability to perform well at a much higher activity level. Subsea revenue for example is almost double over the same 4-year period.
We've also benefited from the growth of our Subsea Service business. The strategic focus business service has resulted in the development of a sustainable source of growth while raising our margin profile. Again, our focus on execution delivered solid fourth quarter Subsea margins at 14.5% and our full year margin average 14.2%, a 260 basis point improvement from last year. 
Fourth quarter subsea orders totaled $1.7 billion, bringing our full year total to $5.5 billion. This resulted in a book-to-bill ratio of 1.2 for the quarter and 1.1 for the year. The total includes our announced awards from the Chevron project in Nigeria, the NI 1506 award in Angola and the Winter Shaw Maria project in Norway. Just as significant, our margins and backlog increased again in the quarter. 
Surface Technologies fourth quarter revenue was $584 million driven by the strength of our international surface wellhead business in our North American fluid control business. Our international wellhead business continued to develop exceptional results. We've established a significant margin presence in the Middle East, that's enabled us maintain a solid backlog while continuing to move our margins. 
Our North America fluid control sales activity was strong for the quarter as order activity held up until December. Overall, our quarterly segment margins of almost 20% are the highest we delivered 2014. 
Turning to 2015. We're responding to the slowdown in our industry as a result of the severe declines in oil prices. We will leverage the momentum of our execution improvements and the strong year end backlog in Subsea at Surface international. We are responded quickly and significantly to the slowdown in our North America businesses by reducing discretionary and capital spending. Most impactful, we have begun the process of reducing headcount company-wide by approximately 10%. The most significant reductions will come from North America where rapid productivity declines are occurring in this short cycle market. We are also using this as an opportunity to strengthen our subsea customer. The improvement process estimated our Subsea business have not only improved our quality and on-time performance, but they've improved our efficiency. These efficiency gains positioned us to deliver a level of activity in 2015 comparable to 2014, but with the smaller, leaner subsea organization. Again, we expect to leverage our execution momentum and strong backlog to not only successfully manage through the downturn, but emerge stronger in the recovery.
Regarding our outlook for subsea orders, we do not expect our 2015 subsea orders to be as strong as 2014. As we previously discussed, many of the larger awards we have expected this year are in Africa. Historically, these audits involve national oil company can have a greater propensity for delay. And in today's current environment, the risk of project delay is greater. Although subsea projects are proceeding, including the awards we received in the fourth quarter, most operators are reassessing their project portfolio looking for ways to achieve significant cost reductions. This is a process that began last year before energy prices began falling and the importance has now become much greater. FMC Technologies has been and continues to be active and directly involved in the reevaluation of projects, particularly with our partners. As a partner, we're proactive in proposing alternative approaches to Project development that includes adopting cost-effective FMC standards, early acceptance of new technologies and different business models that reduce the total cost of development. 
An example of our success in standardization is a 20,000 PSI 350-degree for subsea equipment accepted by a multi-operator consortium. Our investment in the knowledge he focus on the production system, over a step change in savings on equipment costs. Through our unique partnerships, we have the ability to be involved early in design concepts that can optimize the full field development costs. And in today's environment, operators are much more open to different approaches that can result in significant reduction to their development costs.
Shifting now to Surface Technologies. We're now experiencing the effect of the significant slowing in the North America land market. U.S. rig count is falling by almost 500 rigs since the middle of November. We anticipate this decline continuing over the coming months as oil and gas prices have fallen past levels than supposed most current activities. We're now taking actions to address the reduced volumes we experienced in 2015 and we're confident these steps will allow us to effectively manage through the downturn while at the same time not sacrificing our ability to adjust when the cyclical market recovers.
Our North America Surface Technologies activity should remain -- I'm sorry, our non-North American surface technologies activity should remain healthy in 2015. We continue to grow our market position internationally, most predominantly in the Middle East, and expect that backlog that we built will help us minting revenue levels similar to 2014. Customer activity outside North America is typically more resilient through market cycles, but we're prepared to take action should we see markets often beyond the current expectations. 
In conclusion, the performance in 2014 delivered record results, but it also established positive execution momentum that will enable us to successfully overcome the challenges in the current market. We're taking early and meaningful action to stay ahead of the decline in activity. Deepwater and shale remain an important source for oil over future decades and as a result, continue to be an important part of operators' portfolio. To develop these assets requires forward thinking approaches and FMC Technologies is proactively engage with our partners working on new ways to successfully reduce development costs and improve project returns. 
Maryann will now take you through some of the financial details in the quarter and for the full year and provide a more detailed explanation of our 2015 expectations.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Our fourth quarter diluted earnings per share were $0.72. Included in the quarterly results is $26 million or $0.09 per diluted share of foreign currency losses due to the further strengthening of the U.S. dollar. Fourth quarter operational
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Our fourth quarter diluted earnings per share were $0.72. Included in the quarterly results is $26 million or $0.09 per diluted share of foreign currency losses due to the further strengthening of the U.S. dollar. Fourth quarter operational performance was strong across all of our 3 segments. Subsea revenue was $1.4 with operating margins of 14.5%. Surface Technologies revenue was $585 million with operating margins of 19.9%. And Energy Infrastructure revenue was $138 million with the operating margins of 9.9%. Other revenue and expenses included $25 million or $0.07 per diluted share of costs associated with actions taking to derisk our defined benefit plan. These actions were reported. Let me the provide further detail on the segment results.
Subsea Technologies operating profit was $208 million in the fourth quarter. Operating profit improved 12% year-over-year when excluding the $23 million of recognized revenue and operating profit associated with an adjustment for withholding taxes included in our 2013 result. The improving margin profile of our backlog along with the efficiencies gained from the actions we have taken to improve operational performance played a significant role in our full year margin performance. Additionally, we have benefited from the continued growth of our subsea services capability. 
Subsea inbound in 2014 was $5.5 billion and provides a solid base for 2015 revenue and profit. Surface Technologies generated fourth quarter operating profit of $116 million as both our fully controlled and surface wellhead businesses activity levels remained strong throughout period the fourth quarter. Surface wellhead sales for both the fourth quarter and full year represents new record. Fluid Control, both fourth quarter operating income and margins, were strong and sales remained at high levels through the majority of the quarter. However, completion services fourth quarter sales activity was flat sequentially and operating income was down due to disappointing activity in the Canadian market. Orders for Surface Technologies for the quarter were $498 million. Orders for international wellhead continue to remain at strong level, but order activity began slowing for both North America Fluid Control and Surface wellhead. Backlog now stands at $654 million for this segment.  Energy Infrastructure generated fourth quarter operating profit of $13.7 million. 
Now for the Corporate item. Corporate expense in the quarter was $18.5 million. Other income and expense reflects expense of $46.9 million. This includes the previously discussed charge of $24.9 million or $0.07 per diluted share of costs associated with actions taken to derisk our defined benefit pension plan. This also includes foreign exchange losses of $26 million or $0.09 per diluted share to the deferred strengthening of the U.S. dollar. 
Capital spending this quarter was $121 million, primarily directed towards Subsea Technologies infrastructure and service investment. For the full year, our capital spending was $404 million. We repurchased approximately 2.5 million shares of stock in the fourth quarter at an average price of $47.79 per share. For the full year, we repurchased 4.9 million shares at an average cost of $51.01. At the end of the fourth quarter, we had net debt of $670 million. It was comprised of $639 million of cash and $1.3 million of debt. 
Looking at 2015. We have reasonably good visibility of revenues and operating profit for our Subsea business given the backlog of $5.8 billion. In Subsea Technologies, we expect full year revenue of $4.9 billion to $5.1 billion. This estimate reflects a few changes in assumptions from earlier estimate. A strong in U.S. dollar impacting 2015 projection by approximately $300 million. A reduced amount of book revenue given a lower 2015 inbound expectation and a flattish year-over-year service activity. With the current margins in our backlog and the level of execution we expect to continue delivering, we are confident in our ability to attain average Subsea margins for the full year of approximately 15%. 
Moving to our Surface Technologies segment. While difficult to project given the current pace of rigs coming out of the U.S. market, our Surface Technologies revenue will fall from 2014 level. With our large international backlog and our strengthened market position, we expect to have another strong year in International Surface wellhead with performance similar to 2014. 
For our North American business, we are currently assuming a U.S. rig count reduction between 700 to 800 rigs from last year's peak. At this level, we would expect Surface Technologies segment revenue to fall between 15% and 20%. If fully control, we are seeing reduced activity and therefore, expect volume to decline sequentially in the first quarter with continued weakening in subsequent quarters given the recent slowdown in orders due to reduced activity level. 
Activity level from surface wellhead North America and Completion Services will follow similar patterns. Headcount reductions commensurate with current inbound volumes have been completed and additional plans are in place to further reduce headcount in response to continued weakening in the market. We will take actions as appropriate for order inbound level to protect operating margin. 
Full year margin estimates in Surface Technology, we expect to be down between 400 and 450 basis points from our 2014 average count fall by 700 to 800 rigs. In Energy Infrastructure, we should see increased revenue in 2015 with margins in the low double digits on higher activity levels in our loading systems and Measurement Solutions businesses. In addition to the restructuring John and I discussed relating to the Subsea and Surface technology, we are actively renegotiating supplier contracts across all of our businesses to lower input costs. 
Regarding corporate items. We expect corporate expense to average approximately $15 million per quarter in 2015. Other expense net should average of $15 million per quarter in 2015 subject to foreign currency fluctuation. We expect our interest expense to average $8 million per quarter. We anticipate our 2014 tax rate to range between 30% and 32% for the full year. We expect capital spending in 2015 to be approximately $300 million, the majority of our 2015 nonmaintenance capital spending would be directed the with profit in services and investment. 
In conclusion, our Subsea performance should continue to be strong as we execute our backlog and generate service revenue at a level consistent with 2014. Operating margins in Subsea Technologies should increased approximately 15% in 2015, resulting in flat year-over-year operating profit. Our Subsea Technologies businesses will be challenged in North America but with a strong international presence, we think we can deliver revenue between $1.7 billion and $1.9 billion. We are forecasting our International Surface Wellhead business to remain at level consistent with 2014. The North America business will, however, experience significant year-over-year decline. Overall, the segment will see operating profit decline at least 30% from 2014 based on our stated range of U.S. rig reduction. 
Corporate cost should be relatively flat to 2014 and net expenses would be lower a certain cost incurred in 2014 will not repeat. Overall, we expect to deliver solid financial performance from our non-North America land businesses. We will make the structural changes necessary to minimize short-term margin impact while protecting look at them growth strategies. 
Operator, you may now open up the call for questions.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Let me talk about service and I'll let Marryann talk about the conversion rates. Actually our Subsea services inbound in the fourth quarter was the highest for the year. We actually believe the Subsea service number will hold up quite well. Where we are g
componenttext: Let me talk about service and I'll let Marryann talk about the conversion rates. Actually our Subsea services inbound in the fourth quarter was the highest for the year. We actually believe the Subsea service number will hold up quite well. Where we are going to see a falloff is in the North Sea and you've heard some of the actions that is taken. So we see a -- if there's going to be a falloff in services, it will come in the North Sea, but by and large we think the Subsea services, which is a strong margin business for us, is actually going to hold up pretty well, other than the comments in the North Sea, is going to hold pretty well in 2015. I'll let Maryann talk about the conversion rate.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, David. And so as you know, we've got backlog sitting at about 5.8. We're expecting conversion somewhere in about 50% to 53%. As we look at the service business year-over-year, initially we were expecting some stronger service revenues from 2014. Our
componenttext: Yes, David. And so as you know, we've got backlog sitting at about 5.8. We're expecting conversion somewhere in about 50% to 53%. As we look at the service business year-over-year, initially we were expecting some stronger service revenues from 2014. Our first quarter will be soft and we're seeing that being impacted as you question earlier comment really from Light Well Intervention. The installation still remain pretty strong. So about 53% conversion and then subsea services about flattish and then in the balances a small book in turn assumption, just sort of given what John said, somewhat to be uncertainty around 2015.

componenttext: John and Maryann, can you talk about the use of free cash flow and as it relates to the buyback, the buyback in the fourth quarter was probably the biggest I've seen in several years and at least my model estimates. headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: This is John, I'll make a general comment and turn over to Maryann. We were pleased with our free cash flow in 2014 and we made good improvements in capital and obviously we had the earnings. You know that a lot of the investments we made over the last 4
componenttext: This is John, I'll make a general comment and turn over to Maryann. We were pleased with our free cash flow in 2014 and we made good improvements in capital and obviously we had the earnings. You know that a lot of the investments we made over the last 4 years increasing our capacity are starting to wind down? So it made sense that our free cash flow which we successfully generated in 2014 would be directed at stock buybacks where we believe the scotcks have been in undervalued. So that was the thinking there. I think if you go forward in 2015, Maryann commented in her comments that we see CapEx appropriately down and we expect with the revenue number and our continued improvement in working capital, that we'll continue to generate strong cash flow going forward and as long as the stock price remains where it is, and we will continue to be undervalued, I would expect and do expect that our buybacks going forward will probably look like it did in 2014. I'll let Maryann comment a little more on the free cash flow and use of cash.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning, Bill. As John said, we're expecting, even with estimates that we've just provided, with stronger cash flow, improved cash flow performance in 2015 over 2014, you're right, your memory is correct. This is the largest buyback that we've done s
componenttext: Good morning, Bill. As John said, we're expecting, even with estimates that we've just provided, with stronger cash flow, improved cash flow performance in 2015 over 2014, you're right, your memory is correct. This is the largest buyback that we've done since 2007, 2008, a little bit different than the price. We've repurchased a little over 15.7 million shares in '07 and a little over 11.4 million shares in 2008. So we continue to see this as a very opportunistic way to return cash to shareholders and given the valuation right now, we believe strongly in the share repurchase. We're sitting on about 8 million shares remaining at the end of the year on our authorization.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Very good. And then secondly with regard to Brazil, all the turmoil that's taking place with Petrobras, should we be concerned about the Petrobras' backlog at this stage or do you see that kind of converting at a relatively orderly pace going forward?
componenttext: Very good. And then secondly with regard to Brazil, all the turmoil that's taking place with Petrobras, should we be concerned about the Petrobras' backlog at this stage or do you see that kind of converting at a relatively orderly pace going forward?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Bill, we believe Petrobras backlog is secure. Our execution performance on that backlog has been excellent. Our relationship with Petrobras I think has ever been stronger and that's not going to change. There is really uncertainy within the Petrobras orga
componenttext: Bill, we believe Petrobras backlog is secure. Our execution performance on that backlog has been excellent. Our relationship with Petrobras I think has ever been stronger and that's not going to change. There is really uncertainy within the Petrobras organization and we're well aware of that and how that plays out, we will see. But the backlog is secured. Our relationship remains strong, down in vision, I'm sure there will be some moving around to the backlog a little bit. But right now, the backlog's secure and our relationship with Petrobras remains strong and I don't envision that changing.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Ole Slorer with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: The next question is from Ole Slorer with Morgan Stanley.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wonder if you could share with us the kind of discussions that you're having with your key customers at the moment. You made it very clear that they want to bring the costs down and in the process of that, take a pound of flesh out of the oil services i
componenttext: I wonder if you could share with us the kind of discussions that you're having with your key customers at the moment. You made it very clear that they want to bring the costs down and in the process of that, take a pound of flesh out of the oil services industry. So to understand are you negotiating delays of project in your backlog, to what extent are you aiming for price rebates and to what extent are you trying to negotiate whether to change or dour standardize their rig practics so they can take ultimately costs out to better execution?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Ole, first of all, you can appreciate that we are engaged with all of our customers, particularly our partner relationships, I don't think there's a single one where we haven't had exactly the kind of conversation that you're discussing. But let me descri
componenttext:
Ole, first of all, you can appreciate that we are engaged with all of our customers, particularly our partner relationships, I don't think there's a single one where we haven't had exactly the kind of conversation that you're discussing. But let me describe the nature of them. First of all, we believe our Subsea backlog is very secure. There have been a conversations about delaying deliveries, no cancellations, nothing of the nature. The conversations are very direct, given -- and I remember some of these conversations I talked about in the last quarter have been going on for over a year and that's the decline in returns for E&P companies for several years, the huge consent our customers, that's now heightened and those conversation are more intense with the change in oil price. Our customers are telling us that they need to make a step change in the development cost of their deepwater portfolio. They realized, a lot of surprising pressure, they realize they can't get there just by talking about price discounts and so forth. We need to be talking about something more substantial, which means we've got to start working in the difficult industry as a whole, needs to start working differently. The conversation center around standardization. As you know, our company has been particularly successful in driving FMC standards for our partners, most notably In the achievement last year of getting 4 operators to agree on a single spec for next-generation high-pressure high-temperature equipment. I think the acceptance of standards by our customers are now greater than it's ever been as a result of their determination to drive down costs and we think we're in a terrific position to offer the kinds of low cost efficient standard designs that they're going to do to improve their returns. 
The second thing we're talking about is with the operators, is a faster adoption of the technology, particularly new technology that makes step change in the cost of the hardware and the entire production system. FMC has been proposing for some time a unique technologies that directly lower the costs of their production system. And we're getting a lot -- not only does a lot of interest but I think real commitment to proceed with these new technologies, which will make a step change. And then finally, particularly with our partners, there's a recognition that something has to change. This can't be incremental, we can't just roll up our sleeves and work harder and shave things around the edge. We've got to do something substantially different if we're going to expect a significant change in the development cost and there's a real recognition that some of our business but also going to have to change. We're going to have to think a little bit differently about the entire scope of the development, not just individual components and how they're integrated and fit together. We've demonstrated to these partners that there are compelling cost reductions for the entire system if we'll change the way we approach the development of these projects. I mentioned this in my prepared remarks, it absolutely is going to require that our company, the contractor, participate very early in the initial designs and concepts that the operators are using. Because of the many partnerships we have, we're uniquely positioned to participate early and the operators that we talk to are now, really for the first time, encouraging us and encouraging their organizations to let us participate early so we can we really deliver the step change the industry needs.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I imagine that there's going to be some relative winners and losers and other than the alliances, what is it that makes you confident that is just going to be general cost reduction across the whole industry, but something that you can really as an organi
componenttext: I imagine that there's going to be some relative winners and losers and other than the alliances, what is it that makes you confident that is just going to be general cost reduction across the whole industry, but something that you can really as an organization benefit from relative to your peer groups, beyond your alliances, which of course give you a tremendous head start?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. What gives me confidence is, as you pointed out in your earlier comments, we are engaged in open discussions unlike anything before. And the conversations we're having with our customers are about a recognition that we have to have a step change in
componenttext: Right. What gives me confidence is, as you pointed out in your earlier comments, we are engaged in open discussions unlike anything before. And the conversations we're having with our customers are about a recognition that we have to have a step change in costs. It can't be incremental, it can't be 5%, it can't be 10% savings. And I think they recognize that if the kind of the traditional rented down cycle, let's squeeze cost, you can't get there. And so there's no -- we need to talk about that. We know there's going to be some pricing pressure, we know that everybody needs to sharpen their pencil. But if the conversation isn't more than that, they know they won't be able to improve the returns and that's what gives me confidence that the operators are likely to adopt at a faster pace, some of the alternative approaches that we are proposing and as you said, our alliances give us the entry to have those conversations with these customers.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Douglas Becker with Bank of America.
componenttext: The next question is from Douglas Becker with Bank of America.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: John I appreciate your expectations for orders to be down in  2015 for Subsea just given the industry backdrop. Is there still potential for Bongo to be awarded this year and if that's the case, will we see orders up if that played out?
componenttext: John I appreciate your expectations for orders to be down in  2015 for Subsea just given the industry backdrop. Is there still potential for Bongo to be awarded this year and if that's the case, will we see orders up if that played out?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Let me just kind of take it from the top, Doug. A quarter ago, I talked about a long list of projects. That long list of projects, it still exists. Projects haven't been completely shelved, project teams haven't been asked to stand out. They're sti
componenttext: Right. Let me just kind of take it from the top, Doug. A quarter ago, I talked about a long list of projects. That long list of projects, it still exists. Projects haven't been completely shelved, project teams haven't been asked to stand out. They're still being worked. Some of these projects are proceeding and you saw that in our fourth quarter inbound. There were 3 projects. 1 or 2 of them, really we were expecting to happen in 2015 and they got accelerated in 2014. There are other projects, even some in West Africa like Bonga, that appear to be proceeding. But we should expect that virtually all the projects on this extensive list that we originally thought would be inbound in 2015 are going to be reevaluated. The pace of that reevaluation, it's unknown. I mean they're all going to be reevaluated. I think based on the operators intent to try to improve their economics, I'd like to think that most of them are going to go forward. But the timing of that evaluation means that some orders are going to still in 2015, but others are going to end up in 2016, as each of the operators go through this valuation process. So to answer more specific question, yes, it's possible that Bonga continues to proceed at the pace we've been watching it and get it or did in 2015. But it's also like the other projects that have been proceeding along a are going to go through a reevaluation process and if that evaluation process takes longer, those projects are very well move from '15 into '16.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. If we think little bit longer term, has anything changed for more of a secular standpoint in terms of the growth rate you'd expect for more broadly Subsea equipment, could we see a company or growth rate in the high single digits for order
componenttext: That's helpful. If we think little bit longer term, has anything changed for more of a secular standpoint in terms of the growth rate you'd expect for more broadly Subsea equipment, could we see a company or growth rate in the high single digits for orders on a secular basis?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think for some time, we have -- we've been estimating that the future growth rate of conventional Subsea equipment would be in the high single-digit. And again as I said, based on the project list, based on the inventory of undeveloped deepwater discove
componenttext: I think for some time, we have -- we've been estimating that the future growth rate of conventional Subsea equipment would be in the high single-digit. And again as I said, based on the project list, based on the inventory of undeveloped deepwater discoveries, those growth rates are quite achievable. It's not going to be a smooth linear line and so we're going to see some volatility in that growth rate and a lot is going to depend, again, on the pace on which these projects are reevaluated and they're about proceed to and get sanctioned, obviously in a different, in a different design concept, but the pace of which they get evaluate that and he gets action will get us back on that growth curve. But again, just looking at inventory of deepwater discoveries that have to be developed, that high single-digit growth rate is still achievable in the deepwater sector.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Bill Sanchez with Howard Weil.
componenttext: The next question is from Bill Sanchez with Howard Weil.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Maryann, I just want to circle back on the conversion of backlog in subsea this year and the percentage you outlined on the call. FMC has historically been around 60%. I know '14 was expected to be a lower year just given some of the longer lead t
componenttext: Thanks. Maryann, I just want to circle back on the conversion of backlog in subsea this year and the percentage you outlined on the call. FMC has historically been around 60%. I know '14 was expected to be a lower year just given some of the longer lead time orders booked in 2013. I guess I'm a little surprised as to the percentage being as low as it is in '15. Maybe could you talk a little bit more about does FX having an impact on that to some extent and could you give us an idea, I know '16 is still a ways out, but the conversion factor, should we see that moving back to more of a 60% level in '16, if you can help us with that, it would be appreciated.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Bill. So first of all, you're right. Historically, we have seen higher conversion rates. Keep in mind, part of that conversion rate has to do with the size of the backlog and the makeup of the backlog. The greatest component of our backlog right now
componenttext: Sure, Bill. So first of all, you're right. Historically, we have seen higher conversion rates. Keep in mind, part of that conversion rate has to do with the size of the backlog and the makeup of the backlog. The greatest component of our backlog right now is actually Petrobras and as you know that Petrobras business has a longer tail. So in part about the conversion for this year, we are actually seeing a little bit of a slowing coming out of Petrobras. What was initially going to be in 2015 have asked us not to shift a small portion of that into 2016. So no overall change in the total, but rather a shifting from 15 into 16.1. You've talked about the FX conversion. That $300 million that I've talked about really had to do with looking at the average rates in 2014 to 2015. So that $300 million is really off of what our previous estimates. And then our Subsea Service  business, we're expecting it to be a little bit slower. One of our customers, largely in the North Sea, has expressed some OpEx slowing and we're seeing some slowing of that as well. The one into '16, as you say, obviously, it would depend on the timing and the size of 2014 and if we can get, depending on the timing of when that order comes in, we certainly can't see revenues in Subsea in 2016. Again, depending on the timing of that inbound to be flattish with 2015. If we are fortunate enough to see toward the back half of the year, as John talked about, although the reworking of those projects come to fruition, then there's certainly is an opportunity to see growth in that 2016 subsea revenue number.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maryann, can you help us just in terms of the first quarter subsea margin expectations. I know we typically see some seasonality in the North Sea in short cycle businesses, if you will, I guess affecting their margin negatively. Order magnitude, fou
componenttext: Okay. Maryann, can you help us just in terms of the first quarter subsea margin expectations. I know we typically see some seasonality in the North Sea in short cycle businesses, if you will, I guess affecting their margin negatively. Order magnitude, fourth quarter to first quarter, I mean the overall expectation of 15% average. I'm still assuming they will be down in 1Q as some sort of recovery in 2Q forward?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bill. I think on sort of what you saw happening in prior year changes, so Q4 of 2013 to Q1 of 2014, will be similar profile to what we would expect to happen here. So although we do not have 2 of the light well intervention stacks like we had last ye
componenttext: Yes, Bill. I think on sort of what you saw happening in prior year changes, so Q4 of 2013 to Q1 of 2014, will be similar profile to what we would expect to happen here. So although we do not have 2 of the light well intervention stacks like we had last year for recertification, we are seeing some slower activity in the first quarter. So you can assume a similar profile in Q1 of this year like you saw in Q1 of last year.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Scott Gruber with Citigroup.
componenttext: The next question is from Scott Gruber with Citigroup.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I want to follow up on question regarding improving the cost structure offshore. How long do you think it will take for the industry to make those step function changes and project development efficiency. When I think about it on the one hand cycle times
componenttext: I want to follow up on question regarding improving the cost structure offshore. How long do you think it will take for the industry to make those step function changes and project development efficiency. When I think about it on the one hand cycle times are long in the deepwater, while on the other hand it's simply a case of survival for some companies. So John, how do you think about timing in terms of the step function changes?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Scott, in our conversation with our partners, there is a real a sense of urgency. They're anxious to get on with developing their deepwater portfolio and so I think you're going to -- and based on the actions we've seen, we've seen our partners after prop
componenttext: Scott, in our conversation with our partners, there is a real a sense of urgency. They're anxious to get on with developing their deepwater portfolio and so I think you're going to -- and based on the actions we've seen, we've seen our partners after proposing some of our ideas with the technology or a different business model, essentially almost on the spot to make a decision that they're going to rework their project around that different approach. I know one example on some new technology, the project was very close to being sanctioned, all of the design concepts have been largely decided and they headed the subsea organization, had a chance to review our proposed technology and I mean essentially within weeks, they made the decision to adopt that if technology. So I mean -- as an example, but it gives you -- it sort of illustrates do urgency in which the operators realize they have to rework these projects. So this isn't about years. And we saw that even last year, even before the decline in oil, you saw Total's Block 32 Kaombo project, it wasn't years that it took them to rework those projects. It was, I think in that case, just a quarter or 2. So I think given the urgency now and their openness to change, I think the operators are prepared, I hope they're prepared, and the way they're signaling to us is they're prepared to make these step change decisions fairly quickly.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And do you think the overall yield on those efforts in aggregate from a high-level can improve project economics in the 20%, 25% range, at least similar, if not in excess of what the shale producers are targeting onshore in the U.S.?
componenttext: And do you think the overall yield on those efforts in aggregate from a high-level can improve project economics in the 20%, 25% range, at least similar, if not in excess of what the shale producers are targeting onshore in the U.S.?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I definitely believe that we're in that range and the operators are looking for numbers of that magnitude. I think anything significantly less than that, we're talking about incremental change and that's not going to do it. And I think that's what the ind
componenttext: I definitely believe that we're in that range and the operators are looking for numbers of that magnitude. I think anything significantly less than that, we're talking about incremental change and that's not going to do it. And I think that's what the industry is coming to grips with and that's what our company understands. Just rolling up our sleeves, working harder. We have to look even beyond the -- how we define scope of work, because we've got to get at the total field cost if we're going to make these significant changes that people are looking for and that are needed in order to improve the returns.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Jeffrey Campbell with Tuohy Brothers.
componenttext: The next question is from Jeffrey Campbell with Tuohy Brothers.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: First I want to ask you, yesterday Statoil indicated that it had chosen an unmanned wellhead platform concept for its Phase I development of project siding cost reduction versus Subsea. This occurred to me as sort of a regression from the earlier days whe
componenttext: First I want to ask you, yesterday Statoil indicated that it had chosen an unmanned wellhead platform concept for its Phase I development of project siding cost reduction versus Subsea. This occurred to me as sort of a regression from the earlier days when putting as much production as possible on the seabed was seen as a money saver. Is this a unique instance limited to the North Sea or could this be part of a larger trend?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think it's unique. I don't think it's part of a larger trend. Statoil has been quite consistent in their vision for the future and that's everything on the seabed. That hasn't changed and our recent comments and conversations with Statoil, it remains in
componenttext: I think it's unique. I don't think it's part of a larger trend. Statoil has been quite consistent in their vision for the future and that's everything on the seabed. That hasn't changed and our recent comments and conversations with Statoil, it remains intact. So I would say that's definitely a unique situation and not the vision that Statoil has expressed to us.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And further on trying to reduce project costs, some of the industry have suggested that potentially large fields should be developed more incrementally to reach production sooner as a way of managing cost. Is there any evidence of this sort of thinking in
componenttext: And further on trying to reduce project costs, some of the industry have suggested that potentially large fields should be developed more incrementally to reach production sooner as a way of managing cost. Is there any evidence of this sort of thinking in your conversations with your clients?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we worked on 1 project with one of our partners and the original project designed had a significant upfront investment particularly around infrastructure in preparation for future phases and they reworked that project by taking those investments for
componenttext: Yes, we worked on 1 project with one of our partners and the original project designed had a significant upfront investment particularly around infrastructure in preparation for future phases and they reworked that project by taking those investments for future phases, lean to down to just the requirements for Phase I. It made a step change in the investment and improve the returns that they can proceed with their projects. So I think that's definitely one of the different approaches that the industry has to take.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Byron cope with Tudor Pickering Holt.
componenttext: The next question is from Byron cope with Tudor Pickering Holt.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, thinking about your position in the Deepwater Gulf of Mexico, it did certainly sounded like the Subsea services part of your exposure there should hold up fairly well and clearly the long-term JDA will progress. I'm just curious as to what your cust
componenttext: John, thinking about your position in the Deepwater Gulf of Mexico, it did certainly sounded like the Subsea services part of your exposure there should hold up fairly well and clearly the long-term JDA will progress. I'm just curious as to what your customers are thinking in terms of 2015 activity, some of that book intended you tend to get into the Deepwater Gulf of Mexico and how you feel about the outlook there?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, with regard to services, Byron, the Gulf of Mexico, we think it's going to hold up. Because remember, we've got almost $6 billion of Subsea backlog that's going to get delivered and it has to get installed. So that's why we're pretty confident. I me
componenttext: Well, with regard to services, Byron, the Gulf of Mexico, we think it's going to hold up. Because remember, we've got almost $6 billion of Subsea backlog that's going to get delivered and it has to get installed. So that's why we're pretty confident. I mean other than as Marryann mentioned other than the North Sea situation. This equipment is going to be delivered and it's got to be installed. So that helps support solid Gulf of Mexico service revenue related to the backlog of equipment that has to be installed. But we're also quite confident based on the conversations we're having with customers and as you know our intervention stack is en route as we speak to the Gulf of Mexico. We've had really good customer acceptance of the idea. We didn't expect any long-term contracts are free commitments, it's just the nature of the Gulf of Mexico. But we're quite confident that once the vessel and the stack are available, which will happen in second quarter, that we'll be signing contracts. That system is very compelling to the operators and based on their reaction to that system entering the Gulf of Mexico. We're confident that will continue to revenue -- service revenue growth in 2015. And then nonservice, but our partners as you suggested that we do have a very strong market position, mostly driven by our partners in the Gulf of Mexico. With the Gulf of Mexico's large existing infrastructure, it's common for there to be smaller project towards satellite was step outs. Now, they will come under the same scrutiny as a large project with regard to improving return but probably not as intense and we're hopeful that the smaller project of the Gulf of Mexico will in fact, materialize in 2015. They tend to be a little shorter cycle in terms of the awards and therefore, and probably will be able to be even go through a reevaluation process, will probably be a little bit faster than pick the multibillion dollar project. So you combine of that and we're pretty confident that Gulf of Mexico of all our regions will probably hold up as well or better in other parts of the world.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then second unrelated question, as I think about the organizational changes that you put through in the U.S. service business with Surface wellhead business about the year ago, I'm assuming that the reductions to headcount is just reacting to the acti
componenttext: And then second unrelated question, as I think about the organizational changes that you put through in the U.S. service business with Surface wellhead business about the year ago, I'm assuming that the reductions to headcount is just reacting to the activity as opposed to the fairly changing the strategy in terms of how you approach the U.S. Surface wellhead business going forward coming out of the downturn?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. We -- I think both Maryann and I covered that in our comments, Byron. We're going to take early and significant action, but we're not going to jeopardize the trench we put in place and one important strategy for us is our approach to the North
componenttext: Absolutely. We -- I think both Maryann and I covered that in our comments, Byron. We're going to take early and significant action, but we're not going to jeopardize the trench we put in place and one important strategy for us is our approach to the North America land market, the reorganization we did a year ago was pivotal for that change, the new technologies that we're introducing, the acquisition of flowback services of 1.5 years ago, these are all part of our strategy to strengthen our position to differentiate ourselves in the North America land business and that doesn't change. I mean, there will be a recovery and during that recovery, we want to emerge stronger and we've taken steps to implement our strategy to do just that. So these headcount reductions we are dependent out there responding to the downturn in the market.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Rob Mackenzie with Iberia Capital.
componenttext: The next question is from Rob Mackenzie with Iberia Capital.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess question for you, John. Coming back to the pricing question a little bit. Can you give us a feeling for how much you expect to give up in terms of pricing concessions and how much of that may be offset by concessions you get from your vendors, as
componenttext: I guess question for you, John. Coming back to the pricing question a little bit. Can you give us a feeling for how much you expect to give up in terms of pricing concessions and how much of that may be offset by concessions you get from your vendors, as well as a commentary how that in place out in terms of timing?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: So far we haven't seen much but there haven't been many awards that have been made. But just like the last downturn, we expect some pricing pressure and greater competitiveness as we stare at some softness in the market. Let's start with our backlog. I sa
componenttext: So far we haven't seen much but there haven't been many awards that have been made. But just like the last downturn, we expect some pricing pressure and greater competitiveness as we stare at some softness in the market. Let's start with our backlog. I said in my prepared remarks that not only do we have strong inbound orders in the book-to-bill of 1.2 in the quarter, we also increased our margin and backlog. So FNC, we haven't seen a decline in margins. Clearly, our customers are asking for concessions and discounts, but they understand that there's limits to that and we're having conversations with them. But I don't expect significant concessions, particularly on the orders that we've received. Going forward, the competitive environment is going to be a little tougher and we'll see the impact of these lower market in the pricing of bids that are tendered. Having said that, just like last time, we will see the supply chain costs come down and we'll see that partially offset some of the pricing pressure, hopefully we'll be able to hold onto our strong margins that have been represented in our backlog for the last 1.5 years.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great, thanks. My follow-up into the service business, if I may, a little bit. Focusing on Fluid Control. I don't know if we talked a lot about that this quarter artist called. One of your bigger customers, Baker Hughes, is going to be acquired by Hallibu
componenttext: Great, thanks. My follow-up into the service business, if I may, a little bit. Focusing on Fluid Control. I don't know if we talked a lot about that this quarter artist called. One of your bigger customers, Baker Hughes, is going to be acquired by Halliburton who I believe does a lot of their own Fluid Control internally. How are you thinking about, a, how that affects your business going forward after the downturn and, b, more broadly in that sector, that's been North America leverage, do you expect to see additional drivers that are helping to drive that segment in the next cycle?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'll start with the Halliburton. Both companies are important to FMC. I'm sure Halliburton makes their own well service pump, but most of their treating iron the product line, it's bought from FMC and has been for a decade. So Halliburton remains an impor
componenttext: I'll start with the Halliburton. Both companies are important to FMC. I'm sure Halliburton makes their own well service pump, but most of their treating iron the product line, it's bought from FMC and has been for a decade. So Halliburton remains an important customer of FMC. BJ Service before they were acquired by Baker Hughes was an important seller to FMC as well. Again, we're selling them treating iron, swivel joints, product line. But we also have road with Baker Hughes in terms of our well service pump. But remember the well service pump is a small part, we were relatively new to the industry in the well service pump. So it's not a big portion of our business. That's going to be Halliburton's decision how they integrate Baker  Hughes and Halliburton and what they do in terms of rationalizing the equipment that they use. But on the primary product, the fluid control, the flow line, we sold to both companies. So I think the way we look at is there may be some down side just on the consolidation of the 2 companies but there could very well be upside. Going forward, when we get to a recovery, our Fluid Control business recognize any importance of improving efficiency and developing shale, the developing products and services to do just that and I think Fluid Control will continue to contribute to successful development of shale and improving the cost efficiencies as they contributed to the industry. So I think they'll be part of the change that has to take place in shale to improve efficiency.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: The next question is from Kurt Hallead with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: The next question is from Kurt Hallead with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I've had a lot of great color and I want to get your perspective, collective perspective, and do a comparison and contrast on how -- you mentioned some elements about margin and pricing and potential dynamics in 2015 as you book these orders. Cost reducti
componenttext: I've had a lot of great color and I want to get your perspective, collective perspective, and do a comparison and contrast on how -- you mentioned some elements about margin and pricing and potential dynamics in 2015 as you book these orders. Cost reduction by the customer baked, all that stuff. You compare what you expect to see maybe in '15 and '16 to what transpired in 2009 and 2010 because I know as we all look back and do these comparisons that the margin pressure and the pricing pressure was very severe in that period. So can you help us? What's your view of what's going to happen, vis-à-vis what happened in 2008, 2009?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. I think it makes a lot of sense to look back at the last downturn and it serves as an example of what we can expect. So I would say Curt, particularly on those projects that are tendered, this will be outside of our partnerships, we're going to see
componenttext: Right. I think it makes a lot of sense to look back at the last downturn and it serves as an example of what we can expect. So I would say Curt, particularly on those projects that are tendered, this will be outside of our partnerships, we're going to see competitive pressures that will drive the pricing down and I think it will look a lot like we experienced in 2009, 2010. I think some of the differences, to compare and contrast, I think we have more partnerships today, more alliances, more frame agreements today than we did in 2008 and 2009. And it's in the context of those partnerships, not in the pricing concessions of the partnerships, but the nature is very different because those projects aren't tendered so we get to negotiate any changes in the pricing structure and it has -- that has a real effect on margins, a positive one, I would say, in the context negotiating with partner. So we have more partnerships going into this. I would say our relationships with our key customers is also stronger because of our execution performance and that's helpful when you're going into a downturn and negotiate prices. And then finally, our own performance. You will remember, I think you remember in 2010 and 2011, we were struggling with growth and that have an impact on our ability to execute, had an impact on our cost. Remember, we have a lot of people, brand-new people, that weren't as efficient. We go into this downturn very differently than we did in 2009 and 2010. Our execution performance has never been better. Our relationship with our customers has never been better and the maturity of the investments that we made in those 2009, 2010 is very different. Those new employees that we brought on in 2010 and 2011 now have 3 and 4 years of experience behind them. Their efficiency levels are much higher than they were when we went through that last downturn. The investments we made in processes and capacity, those are all behind us now. We are operating successfully, performing well, had an activity level that's almost double of what we were 4 years ago. And that's going to matter in terms of our net earnings because our execution is going to be better, our cost base is going to be -- structure is going to be better. So we go, although 2008 and 2009, what we learned from that downturn, I think will be an example of what we're going to experience this time, we go into this downturn very differently.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's great color, John, thanks. One other follow-up, if I may, on the service front, could you just give us a refresher on what percent of the business in 2014 was International Surface versus North America?
componenttext: That's great color, John, thanks. One other follow-up, if I may, on the service front, could you just give us a refresher on what percent of the business in 2014 was International Surface versus North America?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So our International Surface business could been rough numbers here for 2014, about 45% of the total of Surface Technologies, the balance being largely North America.
componenttext: Yes. So our International Surface business could been rough numbers here for 2014, about 45% of the total of Surface Technologies, the balance being largely North America.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our last question will come from Marshall Adkins with Raymond James.
componenttext: Our last question will come from Marshall Adkins with Raymond James.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just one clarification to start out with. You mentioned the sequential subsea margins in Q1 are going to have a profile similar to Q1 of last year. I presume you're meaning the degradation and margins of roughly 200 basis points is going to be similar now
componenttext: Just one clarification to start out with. You mentioned the sequential subsea margins in Q1 are going to have a profile similar to Q1 of last year. I presume you're meaning the degradation and margins of roughly 200 basis points is going to be similar now that the margins will be similar to Q1. Did I follow that correctly?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: You followed that correctly, yes. I was talking about degradation sequentially. You're absolutely correct.
componenttext: You followed that correctly, yes. I was talking about degradation sequentially. You're absolutely correct.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just want to make sure. Last question for the call, you guys have had a heck of an improvement over the last 2 years improving efficiencies, improving throughputs, et cetera, et cetera. With this downturn, help me understand what happens to those effici
componenttext: I just want to make sure. Last question for the call, you guys have had a heck of an improvement over the last 2 years improving efficiencies, improving throughputs, et cetera, et cetera. With this downturn, help me understand what happens to those efficiencies, do they continue to get better or do we get somewhat less efficient as you're laying off people and things like that?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: Marshall, this is John. We absolutely believe that efficiency improvements we've made particularly in Subsea over the last 3 to 4 years not only are they sustainable, but we're going to be able to continue to build on them. In my prepared remarks, I talke
componenttext: Marshall, this is John. We absolutely believe that efficiency improvements we've made particularly in Subsea over the last 3 to 4 years not only are they sustainable, but we're going to be able to continue to build on them. In my prepared remarks, I talked about this downturn as an opportunity for us to really improve our cost base, streamline the organization and we're going to take full advantage of this opportunity. So our expectation is the improvements we've made not only are they sustainable but we build on them going through this downturn.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
componenttextpreview: I will now turn the call over to Brad Alexander for closing remarks.
componenttext: I will now turn the call over to Brad Alexander for closing remarks.

componenttext: This concludes our fourth quarter conference call. A replay of our call will be available on our website beginning at approximately 2:00 p.m. Eastern today. Alan, you may now conclude the call.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Feb 11, 2015
