componenttext:
Thank you, Cory. Good morning, and welcome to FMC Technologies Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. Our news release and financial statement issued yesterday can be found on our website.
I would like to caution you with respect to any forward-looking statements made during this call. Although these forward-looking statements are based on our current expectations, beliefs and assumptions regarding future developments and business conditions, they are subject to certain risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those expressed in or implied by these statements.
Known material factors that could cause our actual results to differ from our projected results are described in our 10-K, 10-Q and other filings with the SEC. We wish to caution you not to place undue reliance on any forward-looking statements, which speak only as of the date hereof.
We undertake no obligation to publicly update or revise any of our forward-looking statements after the date they are made, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
I will now turn the call over to John Gremp, FMC Technologies Chairman and CEO.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. Welcome to our third quarter 2015 conference call. With me today are Maryann Seaman, our Chief Financial Officer; and Doug Pferdehirt, our President and Chief Operating Officer. I'll discuss highlights from the quarter. Maryann will provide
componenttext:
Good morning. Welcome to our third quarter 2015 conference call. With me today are Maryann Seaman, our Chief Financial Officer; and Doug Pferdehirt, our President and Chief Operating Officer. I'll discuss highlights from the quarter. Maryann will provide specifics on our financial performance, and then we'll open up the call for your questions.
Earnings were $0.61 per diluted share for the quarter excluding the impairment charges of $60.2 million and total company restructuring charges of $18 million. Total company quarterly revenue was $1.5 billion, and operating profit was $224 million, again, excluding the impairment of business restructuring charges. Quarterly revenue for Subsea Technologies was $1.1 billion with margins of 16.9%, excluding the Subsea business restructuring charges. Our focus on execution and the strength of our backlog continues to drive our strong margins. For the full year, we still expect Subsea margins excluding the restructuring charges of around 15%.
Our quarterly Subsea Technologies inbound orders totaled more than $1 billion for the second quarter in a row, bringing our year-to-date total to $2.6 billion. Improved deepwater project economics are imperative to ensure that this critical resource is available to meet the world's future hydrocarbon demand. Our focus on improved execution, standardization, innovative technology and the vendor-based integrated business models for both significantly and sustainably reduce cost and improve returns for our deepwater developments. We recently announced awards for Statoil's Johann project in Norway and Shell's project in the Gulf of Mexico. In the case of both of these awards, we collaborated closely with our customers to identify the most cost-effective solutions to improve project economics.
Given the awards achieved this quarter, the anticipated smaller orders next quarter and sustaining of strong level of subsea services activity, we have further confidence to achieve our targeted full year inbound guidance of at least $3 billion of inbound orders in 2015.
Based on the number of named future subsea projects and the progress made on improving project economics, 2016 subsea market activity has the potential to be on par with 2015. However, given the continued uncertainty of oil prices and capital spending by the operators, we lack the visibility to project subsea orders for next year. Now despite this uncertainty, operators remain committed to deepwater. They're prioritizing capital spending towards production, and they've been successful in improving project economics, all of which support the future growth in subsea activity. Operators continue to show a willingness to accept vendor-based approaches versus the traditional client-specific requirements. An example of this is the additional Chevron to our high-pressure high-temperature joint industry program that was announced in July of last year. Our company, along with 5 operators, are collaborating to help solve the technical and economic deepwater challenges through standardization of materials, processes and interfaces.
We continue supporting our customers' producing assets by leveraging our installed footprint and technology leadership to improve project economics through cost savings and increased recovery. We reached an agreement to produce a multiphase pump solutions for Shell's BC 10 field in Brazil to replace the current separation and boosting modules. At this time, the agreement covers just the first boosting unit.
As we previously mentioned in our second quarter earnings call, the initial response from operators to Forsys Subsea, our joint venture with Technip, exceeded our expectations. Operators' acceptance of our vendor-based integrated approach at the concept stage has been both real and compelling as evident by the receipt of 2 integrated front-end engineering studies in this quarter. The commitment from these operators gives us further confidence that our alliance with Technip will be awarded an integrated EPC contract in 2016.
Turning to the performance of our Surface Technologies segment. Revenue remained flat sequentially as our surface wellhead business outside of North America performed well, offset by further weakness in our North American onshore business.
Given the decline in the North America onshore activity, our fluid control orders remain well below historic levels. The North American rig count is expected to further deteriorate, and in response, customer spending remains depressed, and pricing will remain under pressure. In light of this market outlook, we've taken aggressive action and continue to streamline our North American initiatives to improve our cost structure.
Our surface wellhead business outside of North America performed well in the quarter. We expect activity to remain similar to current levels as we ended the year. However, we expect future months will begin to show the impact of pricing pressure as a result of a deteriorating global market. We're restructuring our operations in response to this weaker market.
In summary, we continue to see a challenge North America Latin market and do not expect any recovery as we go on to 2016. We're taking aggressive action as he manage through this downturn to improve our operating effectiveness, and we continue to accelerate our strategic initiatives to improve our position in the North American onshore market. We remain confident in our ability to deliver full year subsea margins of around 15% excluding restructuring charges. We will continue to strategically restructure our subsea segment in line with anticipated activity levels and also in the way that allows us to sustainably operate with a leaner organization in anticipation of a market recovery.
During the quarter, we achieved important milestones in our effort to improve deepwater project economics through execution, standardization, technology and new business models. These milestones are also evidence of the industry's willingness to adopt a real and compelling changes in how deepwater fields are developed. 
Maryann will now take you through the financial details of the quarter.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Before I review our operations, I would like to note, as announced on Monday, that our third quarter earnings results were negatively impacted by impairment charges, primarily in our Surface Technologies segment of $0.20 per diluted share. W
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Before I review our operations, I would like to note, as announced on Monday, that our third quarter earnings results were negatively impacted by impairment charges, primarily in our Surface Technologies segment of $0.20 per diluted share. We also incurred business restructuring charges mainly in the Subsea Technologies segment of $0.06 per diluted share, as previously communicated. When excluding the impact of these 2 items, diluted earnings per share were $0.61 for the quarter. Our Subsea Technologies segment continued to deliver strong operating results as we executed well in our strong project backlog and cost-reduction initiatives are being realized. Quarter-over-quarter revenue comparisons were negatively impacted by $155 million of foreign currency translation. Subsea Technologies operating profit of $171 million in the quarter. Quarter-over-quarter comparisons were negatively impacted by $27 million of foreign currency translations due to the strength of the dollar. 
Operating margins were 15.6%. We incurred business restructuring cost of $14.6 million in the quarter. Excluding the impact of foreign currency translation and restructuring charges, operating profit was up approximately 4% year-over-year. As you may remember, we communicated on our last quarterly call that we expected to see cost in coming quarters for restructuring in subsea -- our subsea business. Excluding these costs, margins were 16.9% of sequential improvement of 170 basis points when excluding the comparable charge in the second quarter. Our subsea segment has yet to see a decline in activity and, in fact, absent the headwinds from the strength of the U.S. dollar, year-to-date subsea revenue is actually up slightly from 2014. The actions we have taken throughout this year including the significant actions in the third quarter will help us develop a stronger and leaner organization as we prepare for the decline in activity in 2016. We have further restructuring within the organization -- we will have further restructuring within the organization in the fourth quarter. As we enter 2016, our subsea organization headcount will be more reflective of the anticipated decrease in activity due to delayed subsea project inbound. As we see 2016 activity, we will make further assessments on our operating structure. We anticipate an additional $6 million to $8 million of restructuring charges in the fourth quarter. We continue to experience headwind due to the strengthening U.S. dollar. Looking at the first 3 quarters of 2015, the U.S. dollar is significantly stronger against currencies we have the greatest exposure to but not the euro and the real. Subsea revenue for the first 9 months of 2015 include more than $400 million of unfavorable impact, and operating profit includes more than $60 million of unfavorable impact due to the strong U.S. dollar. Absent the foreign currency translation, total revenue year-to-date is slightly favorable year-over-year, and operating profit year-to-date increased by approximately $45 million year-over-year.
Moving to our Surface Technologies results. Surface Technologies reported operating profits for the third quarter of $37 million excluding impairment charges of $58 million, primarily related to our Canadian business and restructuring charges of $2 million. Excluding these costs, operating margins were 10.3%. These results represent continued strength in our non-North America surface wellhead business. As this a later cycle business competitive North America, we continue working off a healthy backlog and so on increase in orders in the quarter. However, current pricing is beginning to reflect a more challenging environment. As John stated, we do not expect to see a recovery before next year on our North American businesses. As discussed in the last earnings call, we are continuing to reduce our operating cost structure for North America while integrated -- integrating related products and services to deliver greater value to our customer. We expect these actions to continue through the fourth quarter and will result in further headcount reductions with an expected cost of approximately $4 million to $6 million. These actions will continue to reduce cost and improve our competitive position as the market recovers.
Segment backlog exiting the quarter stands at $495 million. This continues to predominantly be reflective of our surface wellhead business outside of North America. 
Moving to our final segment. Energy Infrastructure revenue for the third quarter was $97 million. Operating loss for the segment was $2 million as our profitable loading systems results were more than offset by continued slower activity in our measurement solutions business. In the quarter, we incurred restructuring cost of $1.7 million. Given that lower activity levels are likely to continue, we expect to incur additional restructuring charges of approximately $2 million in the fourth quarter due to further headcount reductions.
Let me turn to our corporate items. Corporate expense in the quarter was $15 [ph] million. We expect spending of approximately $17 million in the fourth quarter of 2015, including anticipated restructuring charges of approximately $3 million associated with headcount reductions. 
Other revenue and expense net reflects expense of $22 million. For the fourth quarter, we expect other revenue and expense to be approximately $15 million with a potential for further foreign currency fluctuation increasing this amount. Our third quarter tax rate was 19.2%, primarily due to a change in geographical earnings mix. We expect our 2015 full year tax rate to be between 24% and 26%, which includes the U.S. tax audit settlement discussed last quarter. Capital spending this quarter was $50 million. We expect capital spending in 2015 of approximately $250 million. At the end of the third quarter, we had net debt of $583 million. It is comprised of $712 million of cash and $1.3 billion of debt. We average 231 million diluted shares outstanding in the quarter. We repurchased 1.7 million shares of stock during the third quarter at an average cost of $33.95 per share. In summary, we expect total company restructuring charges in the fourth quarter of $15 million to $20 million. Looking forward, Energy Infrastructure revenue is now expected to be down more than 25% year-over-year with full year margin in the mid-single digits negatively impacted by the results due to slower activity in our measurement solutions business. We no longer expect to see a recovery in this business in the next few quarters, given that activity corresponds to the North American market. As indicated, we continue to take action to improve performance. Surface Technologies revenue is expected to be down nearly 30% from last year due to reduced North American market activity. Full year operating margin will be approximately 10% excluding business restructuring and impairment charges as we will see continued pricing pressure. Subsea revenue for the full year should be approximately $4.6 billion as the strengthening of the U.S. dollar continues to make a greater negative impact. As to the headwinds, we are having our strongest year in subsea revenues. We continue to expect subsea margins excluding restructuring charges of around 15% as we execute well in our backlog and cost-reduction initiatives improve performance. The current market conditions are presenting a number of challenges to our near-term results. However, the actions related to the strategies we are implementing across our businesses will result in long-term cost savings while preserving our capabilities to improve our execution as the market recovers.
Operator, you may now open up the call for questions.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from James West from Evercore.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from James West from Evercore.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, as you think about '16, you made a comment that subsea orders could rival 2015 but you weren't -- not totally confident on that. Where do you get that confidence that it could be similar, maybe even better? Is it just oil prices? Is it customer budg
componenttext: John, as you think about '16, you made a comment that subsea orders could rival 2015 but you weren't -- not totally confident on that. Where do you get that confidence that it could be similar, maybe even better? Is it just oil prices? Is it customer budgets coming out in the next couple of months? Is it behind-the-scenes bidding activity that we're not seeing? What's really the big driver that would increase that confidence.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: The driver -- James, the driver absolutely is the capital budgets of the operator that have not been set and then something else, which is when those projects are settled these projects be included in that capital budget. This is unprecedented for us. In
componenttext: The driver -- James, the driver absolutely is the capital budgets of the operator that have not been set and then something else, which is when those projects are settled these projects be included in that capital budget. This is unprecedented for us. In the past, we had a rough idea of what the capital budgets were at this time, and we knew whether or not projects would be included in the capital budget. Now on the positive side, we know that the number of named big projects that would make up subsea inbound for the market that they exist, and we also know that we made a lot of -- we, meaning the industry -- has made a lot of progress in improving the economics. What we don't know is what the capital budgets are going to be and whether or not these projects are going to be included. And that's the uncertainty that we haven't had in the past that we have today. And I think once we see those capital budgets and we know whether or not these projects are included, we'll have a lot more confidence in 2016 subsea inbound.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. So around the next quarter's release, you probably should have a much better feel.
componenttext: Okay. So around the next quarter's release, you probably should have a much better feel.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Now a follow-up on that with subsea with the restructuring that's underway, the significant restructuring that you're spearheading, do you -- did that change your view of subsea margins at all for next year or is that the incorporated already in the guida
componenttext: Now a follow-up on that with subsea with the restructuring that's underway, the significant restructuring that you're spearheading, do you -- did that change your view of subsea margins at all for next year or is that the incorporated already in the guidance you provided last quarter?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's incorporated. I think we talked about 2016 margins. We know that there is some natural headwinds. We are going to have more of the down cycle pricing and backlog starting to flow through the revenue stream in 2016. We also know that our revenue
componenttext: Yes, it's incorporated. I think we talked about 2016 margins. We know that there is some natural headwinds. We are going to have more of the down cycle pricing and backlog starting to flow through the revenue stream in 2016. We also know that our revenue -- because we'll be going into the year with our backlog that our revenue will be down about 10%. Now those are 2 headwinds that will drive our margins down from what we're experiencing this year, and we've suggested that those margins will be a range of 11% to 13%, bias towards the 13%. We are assuming good execution to get to that 13%. But we're also assuming that some of the restructuring that we're doing now and early next year will help us offset those headwinds in terms of 2016 margins.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: David, I think what we're realizing, I mentioned this in the last call, that the interest by the operators of these different business model has exceeded our expectation. One of the things that we found of particular interest was that those projects that
componenttext: David, I think what we're realizing, I mentioned this in the last call, that the interest by the operators of these different business model has exceeded our expectation. One of the things that we found of particular interest was that those projects that had not been started in terms of concept design and had maybe been sort of shelved in terms of the project economics were the ones at the operators seen the most interest in applying the forces methodology. And the 2 FEED studies that we received the awards for, I think, both fit into that category. These are projects that may or may not have actually been able to go forward had it not been for this different approach. I'd like Doug to comment more of those, specifically on overall the interest that we had in the FEED studies and these 2 awards we've had a little bit more color on what was behind them. Doug?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: David, you may recall last quarter we talked about a wide range of interest, interest from partners as well as non-partners, interest from independents as well as IOCs and NOCs and also the approach we are refining a great applicability in both greenfield
componenttext: David, you may recall last quarter we talked about a wide range of interest, interest from partners as well as non-partners, interest from independents as well as IOCs and NOCs and also the approach we are refining a great applicability in both greenfield as well as brownfields. So we look at these 2 awards that we're discussing today, it actually fits into that category. So the first was for an independent operator who was a nonpartner, and this is a greenfield approach. This is actually the concept stage. So in this particular case, the value proposition was by aligning and having early engagement, making a commitment to partners and close collaboration that they would be able to take anywhere from 18 to 24 months off of first oil delivery. So that was the real value proposition, whilst at the same time recognizing and experiencing the savings that will come from a vendor-based integrated front-end engineering projects. So that was an example. The other example was for an IOC, a partner and in this case, a brownfield application. If you will, this is a field that's going to tie back to an existing host. In this particular example, we got involved at the FEED stage or we are involved in the FEED stage, I should say. I guess this project, I would say, had some economical hurdles that needed to be overcome. The customer recognized 2 things that by using this approach: one, they had the very real possibility of overcoming those economical hurdles, which we certainly expect to be the result; and in addition they saw this as a way to change the behavior within their own company by changing the approach to: one, early engagement; two, committing to doing an integrated project and an integrated delivery of that project or, if you will, an integrated EPC project. And this is really a change of behavior, and this was a catalyst for us receiving that award. So 2 very different projects with different characteristics, but again, it demonstrates the very broad interest that we are receiving in our integrated approach along with our partner, Technip.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So John, earlier, I think was last month or so, you talked about there was 3 potential projects you worked on, and you thought maybe you get 1 of those FEED studies. You come out and you have 2 of those FEED studies now. How many more potential FEED studi
componenttext: So John, earlier, I think was last month or so, you talked about there was 3 potential projects you worked on, and you thought maybe you get 1 of those FEED studies. You come out and you have 2 of those FEED studies now. How many more potential FEED studies you think are out there that you can announce over the next couple of quarters? I mean, are we talking about this as a growing list sort of of tip of the iceberg? Or how should we think about the progress as we kind of monitor the progress of Forsys over the next several quarters?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, absolutely, Dave. We believe that this is the beginning of an industry-wide change in the approach to developing deepwater projects, so we absolutely expect this to be the tip of the iceberg. We're very pleased that we've got 2 operators, which 2 op
componenttext: Well, absolutely, Dave. We believe that this is the beginning of an industry-wide change in the approach to developing deepwater projects, so we absolutely expect this to be the tip of the iceberg. We're very pleased that we've got 2 operators, which 2 operators suggest that on such as short period of time that not only are the potential savings and the impact on returns compelling with the openness and the willingness, as Doug described, 2 different kinds of operators open to a different approach suggest that this could be the beginning of a shift in how the industry develops their fields. We said earlier that there was a -- the interest exceeded our expectations from the full range of operators including even NOCs. All geographies, as Doug said, greenfield and Brownfield it suggests that the breadth of the interest and the application of this different approach could apply to virtually all deepwater projects. And we would expect -- I mean, particularly success breeds success, and I think these FEED studies as we demonstrate that we can deliver the savings as they become EPCI contracts and we execute the savings that will create a momentum that would should only increase the number of projects at the using this approach going forward.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Ole Slorer from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Ole Slorer from Morgan Stanley.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Congrats on the Forsys FEED study as well as your break into the markets. When it comes to these gain to go back to the 2 studies that you won, it sounds like the first one is you're able to fast-track while the second one you might be able to use some mo
componenttext: Congrats on the Forsys FEED study as well as your break into the markets. When it comes to these gain to go back to the 2 studies that you won, it sounds like the first one is you're able to fast-track while the second one you might be able to use some more specific designs, some more specific technologies and products. Could you elaborate a little bit on to what extent the cost savings are achieved by streamlining the execution versus using more specific technologies that you can to the designs around?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Absolutely, it's a combination of both the ability to do the integrated planning and execution and the cost savings associated with that as well as the introduction of the print technologies. But most importantly, it's removing components, actual hardware
componenttext: Absolutely, it's a combination of both the ability to do the integrated planning and execution and the cost savings associated with that as well as the introduction of the print technologies. But most importantly, it's removing components, actual hardware, from the subsea feel design by working together early with the SURF provider with Technip to be able to look at ways that we can streamline the interfaces between the umbilical risers and flow lines and our traditional subsea production system, thus physically removing and permanently lowering the cost of subsea field developments, and that's really where what the objective is. Now on top of that, absolutely, we're going to see benefits, and the benefits are going to come from the integrated planning and execution better delivery improved execution. As John has mentioned many times, the execution and subsea projects has been not great over a long period of time for our industry, and this is a way for us to address that as well. the introduction of new technology will come over time. Just to remind everyone, the actual relationship is just slightly over 120 days old, and we continue -- we do have a robust plan for the development of the technology, but we're seeing right now is actual savings from the physical removal of interfaces or streamlining of interfaces and then the streamlining of the actual installation of the subsea field.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And of the savings, do you think the potential for savings, are they the same in both of these 2 different categories?
componenttext: And of the savings, do you think the potential for savings, are they the same in both of these 2 different categories?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Most definitely, Ole. And I mean, the earlier the engagement, the greater the opportunity set. So you could say if you're engaged at the concept stage you may actually be able to influence the actual savings even greater than if you are involved later in
componenttext: Most definitely, Ole. And I mean, the earlier the engagement, the greater the opportunity set. So you could say if you're engaged at the concept stage you may actually be able to influence the actual savings even greater than if you are involved later in the front-end engineering process so but you would expect similar savings for both of these projects, yes.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bill Herbert from Simmons and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bill Herbert from Simmons and Company.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions on subsea orders. And John, so you prophesied that at this stage notwithstanding that the visibility is somewhat limited you feel like 2016 would be equivalent to '15, and I'm just curious as to the components of that. It seemed
componenttext: Just a couple of questions on subsea orders. And John, so you prophesied that at this stage notwithstanding that the visibility is somewhat limited you feel like 2016 would be equivalent to '15, and I'm just curious as to the components of that. It seemed like into the baseline for the third quarter was running at about $650 million. If you assume that for 2016, that's $2.6 billion, and then you're assuming something close to like $1 billion in major projects in '16, assuming the fourth quarter of this year comes in at close to what you did in the third. And so when you get to that math, I'm just curious about the major project composition, we've been talking about richer for a while talk about Cobalt Camille, we've been talking about mad dog Phase 2, the one that's the biggest 1 which seem to be slipping at least based upon the fact that you're not upsides relative to 15 modest southwest. So can you comment about that formulation and some of those projects, please?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure, Bill. The components of the 26 -- the potential components of the 2016 subsea inbound for us would be let's start with service. Services held up at about a run rate of $1.5 billion. We think in 2016 the installation portion of that will holdup. We t
componenttext: Sure, Bill. The components of the 26 -- the potential components of the 2016 subsea inbound for us would be let's start with service. Services held up at about a run rate of $1.5 billion. We think in 2016 the installation portion of that will holdup. We think some of the maybe discretionary services because of CapEx cutbacks will face some headwinds, so we might come under our past run rate but figure $1 billion plus, $1.5 billion, something under $1.5 billion can be our subsea service number potentially. On the small 1C, 2Cs, the third quarter number that you referenced is too high. We had fairly -- there in the second -- we're watching the 1Cs, 2Cs very closely because we think the Gulf of Mexico market will probably hold up better in this downturn than any of the other markets, and we have a very strong position. In Q1, the small orders coming out of the Gulf of Mexico were very, very light. In the second quarter, they were very strong. In the third quarter, they were not strong. They weren't as light as the first quarter, but they were close to it. So we think that the 1C, 2Cs are demonstrating a kind of lumpy characteristic to become a little hard to predict. But in the 2016, we'd expect -- I mean it's not going to go 0. It's not going to look like Q1 of 2015 but probably continue to look like an average of 2015, so that would make up a number for 2016. And then we would have to win, as we did in 2015, several major awards. And this is where I showed my caution because not knowing capital budgets not knowing whether or not these major projects will be included in the 2016 capital budget, it's hard to predict. But assuming that they would make the cut and included in those capital budgets, we would need a couple of 2 or 3, I don't want to say on which ones and how large, but we would need several major subsea awards. It's hard to imagine getting to an equivalent 2015 subsea inbound without a major Africa project. So those would have to come in, and that's how we get to the components of a 2016 subsea inbound that's on par with 2015. The big question are whether or not these big projects going to be include the capital budgets, and we won't know that until later.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: So specifically with regard to Banca southwest because that's the biggest project close to 53s [ph] we were hoping for earlier this year that possibly that was a 2016 event. How do we feel about that just given the fact that Shell has a lot of with BG and
componenttext: So specifically with regard to Banca southwest because that's the biggest project close to 53s [ph] we were hoping for earlier this year that possibly that was a 2016 event. How do we feel about that just given the fact that Shell has a lot of with BG and oil prices aren't exactly accommodating, what will be the harm in differing that for another year? What's your thought process on that right now?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't have any insights on Shell, but I think you just look the facts, and this is a huge project, it's going to come under a lot more scrutiny and are subject to more delays, the larger they are. It's a national oil company project that has a tendency
componenttext: I don't have any insights on Shell, but I think you just look the facts, and this is a huge project, it's going to come under a lot more scrutiny and are subject to more delays, the larger they are. It's a national oil company project that has a tendency to get the way because you have another partner have to reach approval, and then it's in Nigeria project. So with the I think that puts a lot of question marks around Banca. There are other projects though and Bill, you know them all, mad Dog, Greater Western Flank, Anadarko's projects West Africa. You mentioned Cobalt. Chevron has projects. There is a list of projects that support -- assuming they all make the cut on the capital budgets -- that support the potential inbound that I referenced, but they'd have to come through, you're right. They would have to come through in order to have 2016 look like 2015.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Bill Sanchez from Howard Thill.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Bill Sanchez from Howard Thill.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I guess just one clarification on that prior question. So John, it sounds like to me -- maybe just to specify, do we not expect to see a nameplate award here in fourth quarter additionally?
componenttext: I guess just one clarification on that prior question. So John, it sounds like to me -- maybe just to specify, do we not expect to see a nameplate award here in fourth quarter additionally?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's right, Bill. I mean we're running out a year now. We are looking at the couple of major subsea awards in order to hit our target of $3-plus billion dollars. We got those. We only got a couple of months last. Just given what people are talking about
componenttext: That's right, Bill. I mean we're running out a year now. We are looking at the couple of major subsea awards in order to hit our target of $3-plus billion dollars. We got those. We only got a couple of months last. Just given what people are talking about winding down the year, I just -- I wouldn't include that in their forecast because we're running out of year. So you're right, given every our year-to-date subsea services holdup the 1C 2Cs, which I already mentioned are kind of lumpy. They show up, we get to the $3-plus billion for the year. We're not expecting a major award. And just given the timing, I think that's probably the right way to look at it.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Great. And just one question on subsea margin and Maryann, I guess for you, the 17% roughly in 3Q I think exceeded people's expectations. And given the guide for still 15% average, you're looking sequentially something greater than 200 basis point decline
componenttext: Great. And just one question on subsea margin and Maryann, I guess for you, the 17% roughly in 3Q I think exceeded people's expectations. And given the guide for still 15% average, you're looking sequentially something greater than 200 basis point decline in margins in subsea in 4Q. I guess maybe it would've been a little bit stickier just given the cost-cutting initiatives and still some of the benefits of the higher-priced backlog, the mix of more aftermarket. Can you talk a little bit about that progression? Was there something unusual in 3Q driving a higher subsea margin? It would be helpful.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Bill. So I think in general, you are absolutely right. There's a lot of stickiness all of the cost reductions that are coming through. We expect to continue to see that nothing abnormal between 3 and 4, a little bit of timing. The thing distinc
componenttext: Yes, sure, Bill. So I think in general, you are absolutely right. There's a lot of stickiness all of the cost reductions that are coming through. We expect to continue to see that nothing abnormal between 3 and 4, a little bit of timing. The thing distinct about 4, you're right, we are expecting to see a sequential decline in 4. One of the biggest drivers is Light Well Intervention. As you know, normally in the first quarter of every year, we see Light Well Intervention slowing. In the fourth quarter, we're actually going to see all 3 vessels that operate in the North Sea come off contract, so that's a part of it. A little bit of time we've executed our projects and then lastly we had slightly higher R&D spending in the fourth quarter than we had in the third quarter. So yes, stickiness to all of the good execution we have really just a little bit of timing between 3 and 4. And then again, we're seeing on early slowing if you will or contract removal of the Light Well Intervention.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question is from Byron Pope from Tudor Pickering Holt.
componenttext: Our next question is from Byron Pope from Tudor Pickering Holt.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, in the context of winning your first subsea pump award with Shell for BP 10. You have another -- between separation and boosting, you got another half dozen of those projects could be really just reverse at the high-level how do you see the subsea p
componenttext: John, in the context of winning your first subsea pump award with Shell for BP 10. You have another -- between separation and boosting, you got another half dozen of those projects could be really just reverse at the high-level how do you see the subsea processing opportunity over the next 18 to 24 months boosting versus separation opportunities.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right, Byron. I think in the near term, the next year or so, we've got to put subsea processing projects in the pace of which they're awarded and pursued in the context of a pullback on capital spending on operators redirecting their capital spending towa
componenttext: Right, Byron. I think in the near term, the next year or so, we've got to put subsea processing projects in the pace of which they're awarded and pursued in the context of a pullback on capital spending on operators redirecting their capital spending towards production, certain projects that are in the queue that for very strategic reasons they want to proceed with, all in the context of the smaller capital budget. It doesn't mean that subsea processing technology in these projects aren't very, very compelling financially to the operators. They are. But I think we should assume that they're going to go little bit on the back burner for the next year because of the capital constraints. There are several projects that are out there. Now that our pump is -- we broke in ice our first award we're going to be. We know that we're qualified of the number of operators we're going to be pursuing other projects but they think there might be a temporary slowing in the pace of subsea projects in the next year or so just because of the characterization of the projects in the capital budgets. But as you can appreciate, we are very encouraged that we broke through getting our pump qualified last year. Now we've broken through getting our first award. We're now competing in the processing market. And that market will come. Absolutely, it will come. The economics are very compelling. I just think that the pressure on capital budgets will have an impact on the near-term pace of a project that goes forward on processing.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just a quick question the Surface Technologies, it seems Middle East technology has been dialing the strength with regard to activity levels. And would it be fair to assume that that's been the source of resiliency with regard to your internatio
componenttext: Okay. And just a quick question the Surface Technologies, it seems Middle East technology has been dialing the strength with regard to activity levels. And would it be fair to assume that that's been the source of resiliency with regard to your international surface wellhead this year? And would you expect that business to be relatively stable in that region of the world again as you move into next year?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Byron, you're right, surface international has been a source of resiliency for us in our surface business, but we see that could be approaching an inflection point. I mean to think that our surface international business would be insulated from the entire
componenttext: Byron, you're right, surface international has been a source of resiliency for us in our surface business, but we see that could be approaching an inflection point. I mean to think that our surface international business would be insulated from the entire global deterioration of the market really doesn't make sense. And we think starting next year and next couple of months or so, we'll start to see our surface international business, which has held up so well over the last 1.5 years, under fire particularly in the area of pricing. And I think that this change from of the spelled out in the past. We now see the potential of real weakness, beginning of weakness I should say, as opposed to this business that has held up so well over the last 1.5 years. So we think we're going to start to see the FX of the global deterioration in the oil and gas market service sector start to affect really for the first time in the year our surface international business.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Scott Gruber of Citigroup.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Scott Gruber of Citigroup.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Turning back to the FEED study awards truly great news. John, you mentioned a broader industry-wide change undertake -- underway here just in terms of the way projects are engineered and executed offshore. You specifically highlighted interest from operat
componenttext: Turning back to the FEED study awards truly great news. John, you mentioned a broader industry-wide change undertake -- underway here just in terms of the way projects are engineered and executed offshore. You specifically highlighted interest from operating offshore are they really ready at this point to change the way the their vendors and their contracting processes. Do they need to see the benefits that IOCs and independents reap before shifting?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Actually Scott, when we first announced the joint venture and we began engaging in all our clients on the benefits, quite frankly, we were surprised by the national companies. They operate in the production-sharing contract agreements, which require a com
componenttext: Actually Scott, when we first announced the joint venture and we began engaging in all our clients on the benefits, quite frankly, we were surprised by the national companies. They operate in the production-sharing contract agreements, which require a common tender document. The approach is fixed. It's standard. Multiple contractors bid the projects that's built into the production-sharing contract process. And we really didn't expect for any serious interest from the NOCs, and so we were surprised when the NOCs -- and not just one but multiple NOCs don't rule us out. We are interested. They want improve their economics as well. They saw the compelling nature of this different business model. Now when challenged -- when challenged they, said yes, you're right, we have production sharing contract processes that require tendering but there some options that we have to consider like a design competition upfront, so that we meet our tendering requirements make it still apply this new business model. I think you're right. For the NOCs to go from interest to actual implementation as opposed to the 2 clients that Doug discussed and the awards, it's going to come later because they have natural hurdles you have to overcome, and I'm sure they're going to want to see the success of this different business model before they proceed. But I think we should take an asset of important sign that the industry is prepared to accept different business models even those organizations that have natural barriers to overcome. So I just think we should be encouraged but probably shouldn't assume that NOC is going to be the first one out in terms of experimenting with this new model.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: And was Petrobras one of those that expressed interest initially in the strategy?
componenttext: And was Petrobras one of those that expressed interest initially in the strategy?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, they were.
componenttext: Yes, they were.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from James Wicklund with Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Our next question comes from James Wicklund with Credit Suisse.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on the first pump. And adding Chevron to the lower tertiary study is a coup, so good job. You're still cutting people in surface and in infrastructure, and you talked about how you're sizing the business in subsea. You talked about how we
componenttext: Congratulations on the first pump. And adding Chevron to the lower tertiary study is a coup, so good job. You're still cutting people in surface and in infrastructure, and you talked about how you're sizing the business in subsea. You talked about how we could be at an inflection point in pricing and international service. Maryann mentioned that on a dollar-adjusted basis in this quarter was record up from last year. We've we seem to be at the pinnacle rolling over in a lot of ways and trying to figure out when the bottom is going to be. And I know you and talk a lot about but my question really is how long could this last if big projects are going to be in the oil companies budgets for next year and they're slow to adopt, right? And how long could this last, John? I mean nobody is going to 0. I got that, but how long could we scrape along at the bottom of this bathtub in your business? I know we want to be optimistic, but you're scaling your business for something smaller than it is today. So you got some idea where it's going.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Jim, when we talk to our partners, it's not a single partner who doesn't say they remain completely committed to deepwater. Nobody is abandoning it. Nobody is going anywhere else. The conversation is almost 100% around how can we improve the econom
componenttext: Right. Jim, when we talk to our partners, it's not a single partner who doesn't say they remain completely committed to deepwater. Nobody is abandoning it. Nobody is going anywhere else. The conversation is almost 100% around how can we improve the economics so we can proceed to develop our extensive deepwater portfolio. Just to give you some color, Doug and I was with an operator couple of weeks ago, and they said, "John, our exploration success in deepwater is unparalleled. It is a strength of our company our ability to successfully develop deepwater projects is one of the best in the industry why would be abandoned that strength? What we need to do is take our strengths with your help improved economics and get on with developing our deepwater portfolio." So there's no abandonment of deepwater.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't think it's abandonment, but we could not have a date for a couple of years.
componenttext: I don't think it's abandonment, but we could not have a date for a couple of years.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Except the pace -- the encouraging thing, Jim, is that they're moving quickly. Much more quickly than they think you would've talked to improve the economics. How do you explain that a number of major projects not all won by us were awarded in 2015 despit
componenttext: Except the pace -- the encouraging thing, Jim, is that they're moving quickly. Much more quickly than they think you would've talked to improve the economics. How do you explain that a number of major projects not all won by us were awarded in 2015 despite the capital constraints and the downturn in the industry because these projects were reworked to improve their returns. I'm confident that this will only accelerate the success, and improving economics will only accelerate in the years to come. We should be encouraged by the early adoption of these new business models. Nobody thought that in just over 100 days, 2 companies would decide to turn upside down their historic business models for the purpose of improving economics. So this is going to gain momentum. And to the extent that the capital budgets, which were already directed away from exploration to production, start to incorporate these major projects. So you're right, how long...

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't disagree with you on any point, it's just the disconnect I have seen between what investors think is quick and what happens, especially in deepwater with IOCs and what in the industry is called quick, is often a disconnect. And I just my concern i
componenttext: I don't disagree with you on any point, it's just the disconnect I have seen between what investors think is quick and what happens, especially in deepwater with IOCs and what in the industry is called quick, is often a disconnect. And I just my concern is like ordering deepwater rigs, we're not going to do it for a couple of years or 10, while your guys can stay committed to deepwater. When do they get the budgets to develop is the issue. And my concern is they may not be in this year's budget or next year's budget or the next year's budget. What you're doing is great and right and will work, but the rate of adoption is my biggest concern.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think that's our concern as well, but again, that's why we're so encouraged that this adoption is faster than anybody at your point anybody that's ever seen this industry and that gives us some encouragement now. What are we doing and responses
componenttext: Yes. And I think that's our concern as well, but again, that's why we're so encouraged that this adoption is faster than anybody at your point anybody that's ever seen this industry and that gives us some encouragement now. What are we doing and responses we can that into our control how fast they adopt this. We're trying to make sure that we can adequately to restructure our business during this uncertain period of time without jeopardizing our ability to execute and succeed when the market and eventually comes back. And so far based in the numbers we have seen and the baseload that we get from our partners that we can achieve this. But you're right, I mean there's an uncertainty. And in terms of the level of activity and we're watching it carefully. And right now, we think we've been able to balance the necessary restructuring in keeping our core capability for when the recovery comps.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Mark Brown from Seaport Global Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Mark Brown from Seaport Global Securities.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just get any kind of update on Petrobras with you and many of your competitors a backlog associated with the company and to what extent you expect to see a risk of impairment or slowdown in the deliveries from either you or the industry, in ge
componenttext: I wanted to just get any kind of update on Petrobras with you and many of your competitors a backlog associated with the company and to what extent you expect to see a risk of impairment or slowdown in the deliveries from either you or the industry, in general.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. You recalled 2.5 years ago, we received one of the largest Petrobras awards for pre-salt Christmas trees and pre-salt manifolds. That was 4 years requirement. We got the bulk of the manifold awards and very large tree awards at that time. That back
componenttext: Right. You recalled 2.5 years ago, we received one of the largest Petrobras awards for pre-salt Christmas trees and pre-salt manifolds. That was 4 years requirement. We got the bulk of the manifold awards and very large tree awards at that time. That backlog represents 17% [ph] of the company's entire backlog. There has been clearly pressure by Petrobras, in some cases cancellation, although we've seen no cancellation. Instead, we have seen some rescheduling of that 4-year requirement of Petrobras that was in our backlog. That actually worked our favor. We are able to avoid some expansion cost and spread out the deliveries over a period that takes us through mid-2019, and we think that backlog will stay intact. Again, lots of pressure for Petrobras, but we think it will stay intact. The margins have held up. There's a lot of pricing pressure. But largely, we think the margins will be able to hold up. And as a result, we see no risk of any type of impairment. We obviously are going through a major restructuring to resize ourselves, but we think we can use that Petrobras backlog to get us well into 2019. Now beyond that, we're obviously anticipating the market starts to improve in Brazil. But that's the story for us. We benefited by the large awards we won almost 3 years ago, and we can stretch those up in 2019 and size our organization accordingly.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: All right. And just a follow-up on the different topic. Obviously, the big merger that was announced recently affecting the subsea space, I was wondering if that changes your strategy in any way or if you think there might be additional consolidation or c
componenttext: All right. And just a follow-up on the different topic. Obviously, the big merger that was announced recently affecting the subsea space, I was wondering if that changes your strategy in any way or if you think there might be additional consolidation or combinations in the overall subsea space going forward.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I'm assuming you're referring to the Schlumberger acquisition of Cameron. They had a joint venture, a subsea joint ventures between Cameron and Schlumberger for almost 3 years. The acquisition by Schlumberger shouldn't directly affect that joint venture O
componenttext: I'm assuming you're referring to the Schlumberger acquisition of Cameron. They had a joint venture, a subsea joint ventures between Cameron and Schlumberger for almost 3 years. The acquisition by Schlumberger shouldn't directly affect that joint venture OneSubsea, which we've been competing against for 3 years. So there's not a significant change in that structure with regard to subsea. Our response to that has been to focus on our alliance with Technip and our joint venture on Focus and with Forsys Subsea. And obviously, we're encouraged by the results we had last quarter's results for that that focus. In terms of consolidations in the industry, I really couldn't speak to that. During downturn, it's not uncommon for industries, and I don't think our industry will be any different.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Robin Shoemaker from Keybanc.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Robin Shoemaker from Keybanc.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: John, I was wondering if you could shed any light on this year's breakdown between -- in subsea, between backlog conversion to revenue and customer support. It looks to me like backlog conversion this year is around 50% level, but maybe I'm wrong on that,
componenttext: John, I was wondering if you could shed any light on this year's breakdown between -- in subsea, between backlog conversion to revenue and customer support. It looks to me like backlog conversion this year is around 50% level, but maybe I'm wrong on that, comparable to last year, and it's usually a little higher as backlog declines.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, Robin, you're right. The 50% conversion rate is about right. Historically, we've got a higher number but because we've had these large projects, particularly Petrobras, this conversion number is a bit lower, but 50% is a good number. Subsea services
componenttext: Yes, Robin, you're right. The 50% conversion rate is about right. Historically, we've got a higher number but because we've had these large projects, particularly Petrobras, this conversion number is a bit lower, but 50% is a good number. Subsea services is a book and turn business, and we said that's about $1.5 billion of the revenue. So you take that conversion rate of our backlog and then we went into almost record backlog in 2015 of 50% plus the subsea services book and turn and then the smaller book and turned, which is probably the smallest piece of all 3 of those, you get to the revenue recognition for 2015 of $4.6 billion.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: 4.6. Right. Okay. So on another topic, I want to ask on the fluid control business and whether you observe what's happening there similar to previous downturns where the purchases dry up very substantially but sort of create a deficit of inventory that le
componenttext: 4.6. Right. Okay. So on another topic, I want to ask on the fluid control business and whether you observe what's happening there similar to previous downturns where the purchases dry up very substantially but sort of create a deficit of inventory that leads sort of like a coiled spring when the market does recover. But in terms of pump sales or treating sales, are we at the very, very low levels we've seen before and working down inventories rapidly?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Robin, absolutely. The fluid control business is following the same pattern as you just described. The challenge is as we see further reductions in activity in North America, it just adds the idle capacity, which adds to the cannibalization that's going o
componenttext: Robin, absolutely. The fluid control business is following the same pattern as you just described. The challenge is as we see further reductions in activity in North America, it just adds the idle capacity, which adds to the cannibalization that's going on versus that coiled spring releasing. So the amount of energy being stored in the spring is increasing, but the release of that is further delayed because of the continued deterioration of the North American market.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Judd Bailey from Wells Fargo Securities.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Judd Bailey from Wells Fargo Securities.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I had just a follow-up question on your margins for subseas next year in reference to the guidance between 11% and 13%. John, you mentioned your goal and confidence in getting something towards the higher end of that range. I'm just curious if you were to
componenttext: I had just a follow-up question on your margins for subseas next year in reference to the guidance between 11% and 13%. John, you mentioned your goal and confidence in getting something towards the higher end of that range. I'm just curious if you were to come at the low end, what are the variables of think about that would cause you to come at the lower end of that range? Would it be lower utilization, lower intervention subsea services? Or how should we think about the difference between the high and low end of that range?

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think, you got it, Judd. Execution is always a variable. We're very, very pleased the progress we executions, so we don't expect anything that you manage a lot of projects. So execution would take us to the low end. You're absolutely right on the servic
componenttext: I think, you got it, Judd. Execution is always a variable. We're very, very pleased the progress we executions, so we don't expect anything that you manage a lot of projects. So execution would take us to the low end. You're absolutely right on the services side we had headwinds on services, which is a book-and-turn business that's not in backlog, so that would affect it. And then pricing register medicine on the pricing pressure including some of our service contracts. So even though, generally, our pricing and backlog, at least historically in downturns, stayed intact, it's under a lot of pressure, and so I think there could be some pricing concessions particularly in the service side, service activity and execution could all lead us to the lower end of the range. Now again, as you heard in my remarks, I think we're biased towards the high end because we've made such a good progress and execution we fully expect that to continue and more focused on that continuing into next year. And we think with our good execution performance, we're in a position to push back on some of the price concessions because of our execution performance for the operator. So that's -- I think you're on the right track to the low end.

headline: FMC Technologies, Inc., Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And then just one clarification, did you say the potential for price concessions for orders that are already in backlog?

componenttext: No. I was referring to service rates. So service as a book-an- turn business. We have negotiated rates. We've come under a lot of pressure to renegotiate those rates, and that's why that would affect margins in 2016 because it's a book-and-turn business.
